#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Gouda
#Text=Gouda is a city in the province South-Holland in The Netherlands .
#Text=It is a typical Dutch city with many old buildings , canals and pretty sights , and is a popular destination for a day trip .
#Text=It is also a good base for exploring the rest of the Netherlands , thanks to its great rail- and highway connections .
#Text=The city is famous for its cheese , its 15th century town hall and the amazing glass windows in St. Janskerk , but there is a lot more to see and do .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Gouda has a population of about 71,000 .
#Text=As well as its cheese , Gouda is also famous for its stroopwafels ( syrup waffles ) , candles and its clay pipes .
#Text=Most of the city is below sea level .
#Text=The lowest point of the Netherlands can be found a few kilometers outside the city and is marked by a monument .

#Text=Gouda is pronounced khow-da ( [ ˈɣʌudaː ] ) , with the ' g ' pronounced similarly to the ' ch ' in ' loch ' , not with a hard ' g ' like how native English speakers pronounce the name of the cheese .
#Text=The " ou " sound should rhyme with c ow or the German h au s .
#Text=Saying the name correctly will win you points with the locals !
#Text=VVV Gouda ( Tourist information ) , Markt 35 ( at the Goudse Waag at the central square ) , ☏ +31182-589110 , ✉ info@welcometogouda.com .
#Text=Apr-Oct 10.00-17.00 ; Nov-Mar Tu - Su 10.00-14.00.
#Text=History
#Text=Gouda is named after the river Gouwe and the Van der Goude family , who built a castle on the Gouwe River in the 11th century .
#Text=At that time , the area was swampland .
#Text=Over the next two hundred years peat was collected and the land was developed .
#Text=In 1225 , a canal was built connecting the Gouwe River with the Oude Rijn ( part of the Rhine delta ) .
#Text=This was used to help ship goods to France and further afield .
#Text=This provided a safer route than traveling by sea .
#Text=This resulted in a surge of economic activity around Gouda and the town gained importance .
#Text=In 1272 , it was declared a city by count Floris V.
#Text=Most of the canals were built around this time .
#Text=Over the years , there have been fires ( 1361 , 1438 ) , occupations ( 1572 ) and plagues ( 1574 , 1625 , 1636 , 1673 ) .
#Text=In 1577 , the castle was destroyed .
#Text=Despite these disasters , Gouda is still a beautiful place to visit .
#Text=In 1667 a tax was introduced on the locally produced cheese .
#Text=This raised a lot of money for the town .
#Text=In 1668 , the Waag ( cheese weighing house ) was built , to weigh the cheese and collect this tax .
#Text=By train
#Text=There are two train stations in Gouda - Gouda ( the main station , a 5 minute walk to the Markt ) and Gouda Goverwelle ( in suburbia ) .
#Text=For the timetable check NS ( in English ) .
#Text=Trains have been running between Gouda and Utrecht since 1855 ; in 1944 the old train station was damaged by Allied bombing .
#Text=There are five ways to travel to Gouda by train .
#Text=Utrecht CS - takes less than 20 minutes .
#Text=Take a train in the direction of Rotterdam or The Hague .
#Text=Six trains an hour .
#Text=The Hague and Rotterdam - takes less than 20 minutes .
#Text=Take a train towards Utrecht .
#Text=Gouda is right in the middle of these train lines .
#Text=Eight trains an hour .
#Text=Amsterdam - takes 40 – 60 minutes , depending on where in Amsterdam you are .
#Text=There is one slow direct train ( ' Sprinter ' ) per hour .
#Text=It is also possible to take the intercity train to Utrecht and transfer there , which takes about the same time .
#Text=Leiden - take the train to Alphen aan den Rijn and from there you can take a train to Gouda .
#Text=Before and after working hours , there are direct trains running from Leiden to Gouda .
#Text=When you arrive at the train station , take the exit called " Centrumzijde " or just " Centrum " .
#Text=There should be a sign pointing you to the city centre .
#Text=If you ca n't find it , just go the way most people go and you will be in the city centre very soon .
#Text=If you want to take a taxi , there will most likely be drivers waiting for customers .
#Text=They will pick up you up on the street outside the station .
#Text=If there are n't any taxis around , you can call them .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Buses stop at the train station .
#Text=Most of them are operated by Arriva , some of them by Connexxion .
#Text=There are buses connecting Gouda with Rotterdam , Utrecht , Zoetermeer , Leiden , Waddinxveen , Bodegraven , Schoonhoven , Reeuwijk-Brug and some more towns .
#Text=Buses are slower and more expensive than trains .
#Text=If you have the option , choose the train .
#Text=By car
#Text=Gouda is directly located on the A12 and A20 .
#Text=The Hague - about 20 mins .
#Text=Take the A12 towards Utrecht
#Text=Rotterdam - about 15mins .
#Text=Take the A20 towards Utrecht .
#Text=Amsterdam , Schiphol or Leiden - Take the A4 towards Leiden , then the N11 ( via Alphen aan den Rijn ) .
#Text=Or ( slightly longer , but without leaving the motorway ) , take the A4 to [ [ The Hague ] and then the A12 to Gouda .
#Text=Parking is cheapest in one of the large parking lots just outside the city center ( about € 1,40 - 1,80 per hour , max € 8 - 10 per day ) .
#Text=They are called Klein Amerika , Schouwburgplein and Vossenburchkade and are well indicated .
#Text=There are two public garages in the city center , called Bolwerk and Nieuwe Markt .
#Text=These are located closer to the interesting part of the city , but are also a bit more expensive ( about € 12 a day ) .
#Text=It is not advised to park on the streets because that 's really expensive .
#Text=By plane
#Text=The nearest airports are in [ [ Amsterdam ] ] ( Schiphol Airport ) and [ [ Rotterdam ] ] ( Rotterdam The Hague Airport ) .
#Text=By boat
#Text=There are no ferry or waterbus services to Gouda , but when you own a boat , there are facilities to stay in Gouda .
#Text=More information can be found at Welkom in Gouda .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The city centre of Gouda , like many other historic Dutch cities , is surrounded by a circular canal .
#Text=The city only started to expand beyond this circle in the late 19th century , so most historic sights can be found within it .
#Text=It is also the main shopping district of the city .
